subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Sorry for being dense, but in my case, I pronounce taught and tot the same exact way. So it wouldn t really help to have me just use the vowel I use
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:

>
> To get to your observation let me digress into an issue I have that
> may help. It's about vowels but please bear with me. People with my
> accent do not differentiate between Ox, Ah and Awe. I usually make the
> sound Ox for all such words but sometimes if I pay close attention to
> my own speech I notice that I'll sometimes say a word with the Ox
> sound and sometimes the same word has what might pass for an Ah sound.
> Because I *mostly* use the Ox sound, I must *just* use Ox otherwise I
> might write "tot" sometimes as Tut+On+Tut(which is fine) but sometimes
> as Tut+Awl+Tut which may sound right to me but would not be for others
> (eg most British). An especial disaster if I were writing about a tot
> who was taught Quickscript.

Sorry for being dense, but in my case, I pronounce "taught" and "tot"
the same exact way. So it wouldn't really help to have me just use the
vowel I use most of the time, would it?


>It is this
> "semi-phonetic" nature of the script

I like that phrase, as it might more accurately describe QS than others.

Thanks!

Paul
